thread.title: Newspaper headlines: 'Don't lock up low-risk paedophiles'
thread.title_full: Newspaper headlines: 'Don't lock up low-risk paedophiles'

title: Newspaper headlines: 'Don't lock up low-risk paedophiles'
text: Messenger Image caption The Times leads on Britain's most senior child protection police officer, Simon Bailey, who says paedophiles who view indecent images should not be given any criminal sanction unless they pose a physical threat to children. He said the policing system had reached "saturation point" due to increasing reports of sexual abuse, the Times continues. Image caption The Daily Telegraph says UKIP is in a state of open civil war after former leader Nigel Farage publicly warned that the party would collapse unless its only MP, Douglas Carswell, was thrown out. It comes amid claims Mr Carswell frustrated Mr Farage's chances of a knighthood - Mr Carswell insists he made every effort to ensure UKIP got its fair share of honours. Image caption The Guardian looks ahead to US President Donald Trump's first address to Congress, in which it says he will outline priorities including a massive hike in military spending at the expense of foreign aid and environmental programmes. The paper notes that the US already spends more on the military than the next eight countries combined. Image caption The Daily Express says Theresa May faces a row with Brussels over plans to curb migrant numbers from the European Union next month. "MPs expect the prime minister to announce an end to free movement on the day she formally puts Britain on the road to Brexit," reports the Express. Image caption The Daily Mail says BBC director general Tony Hall is demanding "urgent reassurances" after the Mail claimed inspectors from Capita, which collects the licence fee for the corporation, were picking on vulnerable families. Image caption The Sun has a story on what it calls "fury" in the forces, with news that RAF servicewoman will wear trousers instead of skirts on parade. "Frocks away," exclaims the paper's headline. Image caption The Daily Star reflects on the chaos at the Oscars where the award for Best Picture was initially given to La La Land instead of Moonlight by mistake. Image caption The Metro leads on the ex-boyfriend who murdered a young couple after he Googled "16 steps to kill someone and not get caught". Andrew Saunders stabbed Zoe Morgan, 21, and Lee Simmons, 33, as they arrived for work at Matalan in Cardiff. He admitted the murders in court in December. Image caption The Daily Mirror leads with more on the thief who has been convicted of raiding music mogul Simon Cowell's home. The Mirror says Darren February killed a motorcyclist in a hit-and-run incident just days later. February was convicted last year of causing death by dangerous driving.
